cell.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: THE RUSSIAN BLUNDER
div.p: The feeling at home in regard to the North Sea incident, we are told this morning, is at fever heat, and all political parties are united in demanding full reparation for the lives of the fishermen. The decision of the Cabinet Council at this morning's meeting will be awaited with the most extreme anxiety. The telegrams from Gibraltar and Malta show that everything is being made ready for the terrible eventuality of the outbreak of hostilities. The excuses offered for the outrage by Admiral Rodjestvensky, in command of the Baltic Fleet, and by Prince Keretelli, of the Imperator Alex ander, as given in our telegrams of yesterday and to-day, are utterly unintelligible. The

Admiral announces in an interview, published in a Madrid newspaper, that, before leaving Libau, he had declared his intention of attacking any ship approaching his fleet. This statement is absurd as no trawler can be considered as coming within the category of a vessel likely to attack the Baltic fleet. Trawlers, as a rule, steam at the rate of eight knots an hour at their most rapid speed. When in the immediate neighbourhood of the nets on the North Sea fishing grounds the trawlers are either at anchor or heaving in their cable for trawling purposes. But to an ordinary seafaring man it is well understood that all ships, when prudent, have to keep clear of trawlers, when either at steam or at sail, owing to the fact that this class of vessels are forced to be either permanently or temporarily at anchor. The allegation of Prince Keretelli, which might be construed to the effect that it was possible to mistake a steam trawler for a torpedo-boat, is ludicrous in the extreme. A steam trawler can no more be mistaken for a torpedo-boat than can a dahabieh be mistaken for a first-class battleship. The contour of these two classes of vessels is utterly dissimilar, for a steam trawler is a broad-bottomed boat with a funnel and lights accordingly, while a torpedo-boat is, as a rule, a wedge shaped vessel, of a most abnormal, and consequently easily distinguishable, type. The torpedo-boat lies low in the water, while the trawler floats on the bosom of the ocean. The most ignorant landsmen, whose knowledge of ships is only derived from the illustrated papers, could tell the difference between these two classes of vessels.

Another extraordinary statement made by Prince Keretelli is that the trawlers were signalled to state their nationality. He goes on to say that they refused to comply and advanced among the battleships. This is absurd, because a trawler should, whether steam or sail, be well known to any qualified naval or mercantile officer. Moreover, it is quite easy to make out the nationality of a trawler by the indications of the fishing grounds. Conse-quently, trawlers do not exhibit signals of nationality, save and except those signals enforced by the Board of Trade. Again, it is not even obligatory, nor is it customary, on a trawler to fly a distinguishing national flag either by day or by night. In fact, no vessel can make known its nationality at night, except, for example, the first-class liners, who have their own private codes of signals for the purpose, which are well known to all signal stations. But a trawler has no such facilities because there is never any need for these vessels to make their nationality known either by night or by day, as fishing boats are as a general, rule confined to their own fishing grounds and do not move beyond them. The Prince goes on to declare that the report of a gun was heard, and that thereupon the Russian Admiral ordered his vessels at once to form in line of battle and reply to the fire. This also is ridiculous for trawlers do not carry guns except for use as a signal of distress. The report, which preyed on the excitable nerves of the terrified Russians, may possibly have been the detonation of a discharge of dynamite. Trawlers are not permitted to, but sometimes do, make use of dynamite in order to kill fish for a better haul. The trawlers hurl the detonator into the water and an explosion follows, but no naval officer could, under any circumstances, mistake such an action for the discharge of a cannon. Even if we assume that the Russians were so stupid as to make such a childish mistake, why then did they sail away without endeavouring to sink these "torpedo-boats" or save the lives of those on board the vessels they had attacked? We need not, however, attempt to continue our analysis of these excuses, for they are evidently made solely in order to hide a most gross error of judgment, induced by sheer nervousness. But this is no excuse in the case of the commander of a fleet, who should be selected for the post in virtue of the soundness of his judgment. The fact that the Admiral believed that Japanese torpedo vessels were infesting the North Sea, 6,000 miles from the seat of war, shows either that he had not a particle of confidence in his Intelligence Department, or that he has been reduced to such a state of tension owing to the Japanese victories, that he has lost even the remnants of that courage and clear-headedness which seamanship always demands as its primary qualifications.

div.head:
NORTH SEA OUTRAGE.
FEELING AT FEVER HEAT.
ALL PARTIES UNITED.
OMINOUS NAVAL ORDERS.

div.p: The feeling in England is at fever heat. All parties are absolutely united in insisting upon full reparation. Lord Rosebery and Si H. Campbell Bannerman have publicly, declar ed that they will support the movement.
The view in official circles here is that it is imperative that a satisfactory settlement should be arranged before the Baltic fleet reaches a certain point on its outward voyage. (Reuter.)
Admiral Rodjestvensky's official report has reached here. He says that two torpedo-boats were among the trawlers. The Admiral deplores the loss of life.
Negotiations are still proceeding. There is reason to believe that no ultimatum has been presented by Great Britain, who has not gone beyond pressing for a definite reply.

The opinion in Russian official circles is that England's impatience is not justified, in view of the difficulty of the circumstances. It is suggested that the explanations of Admiral Rodjestvensky, which have been transmitted to the British Embassy, should form the subject of a joint enquiry. (Reuter.)
The Channel fleet is ready for sea at a moment's notice.
The Cabinet has been summoned for tomorrow.

H.M.'s battleship Queen and 9 destroyers have sailed from here for an unknown destination. A division of the Mediterranean Fleet, now at Fiume, has received urgent orders to unite with the division which is at present at Pola, and to proceed westwards.
The Channel Fleet, which cleared for action yesterday, sails to-day, ostensibly for a sham
attack on the Rock.
(Reuter.)
The two divisions of the Mediterranean Fleet, which are respectively at Pola and Fiume, have sailed, it is believed, for Gibraltar. (Reuter.)

div.head:
RUSSIAN ADMIRAL'S REPORT
THE TORPEDO ATTACK.
SYMPATHY FOR VICTIMS.

div.p: Admiral Rodjestvensky. has telegraphed, concerning the North Sea incident, that two strange torpedo-boats were amongst the fishing boats. He expresses his regret at the death of the English fishermen.
Spain has authorised the Russian vessels to take on 400 tons of coal each. (Havas.)

(Official). Two telegrams have been received from Admiral Rodjestvensky. The first one declares that two torpedo-boats, with no lights showing, attacked the leading vessel of the fleet. The latter then swept the sea with her searchlights, and opened fire, whereupon the presence of several small steamers, resembling fishing vessels, was discovered. The fleet endeavoured to spare the latter, as soon as the torpedo boats disappeared.

The Admiral declares that no torpedo-boats accompanied his fleet. One of the strange torpedo-boats was sunk. The other, being only slightly damaged, remained till morning near the small steamers. The fleet did not assist the latter because, in view of their obstinacy in crossing the Russian line, they were suspected of complicity in the attack. Several of the fishing vessels showed no lights, and the remainder only put them out very late.

The second telegram stated that the fleet met fishing boats to the number of several hundreds, and showed them every considera- tion, except where they were in company with foreign torpedo-boats. The Admiral went on to say "If there were also on the scene of the occurrence fishermen who were imprudently involved in this enterprise, I beg, on behalf of the fleet, to express my sincere regret for the unfortunate victims of circumstances under which no warship could have acted otherwise, even in time of profound peace." (Reuter.)

div.head: NORWEGIAN SHIP FIRED ON.
div.p: A Norwegian ship was fired upon by the Russians in the English Channel on the 23rd t inst. Firing ceased as soon as the ship hoisted a ber ensign, (Havas.)

div.head:
FLEET EN ROUTE FOR TANGIER
A NAVAL COUNCIL.
div.p: The Baltic Fleet is expected to leave her for Tangier to-day. Each vessel has been permitted to take 400 tons of coal. All yesterday afternoon the Russian Consul conferred with Admiral Rodjestvensky on board the flagship The Admiral subsequently summoned the captains, and had a long consultation with them. (Reuter.)

div.head:
THE WAR.
RUSSIAN ATTACK.
div.p: An artillery duel took place last night on the north bank of the Sha-Ho. The Russians were attacking.
(Reuter)

div.head: EXILES.-
div.p: Three "undesirable" Greeks are to be repatriated by the Hellenic consular authorities on the first ship leaving for Greece.

div.head: "AT HOME-
div.p: The "at home" to be given by Canon and Mrs. Ward will take place on Tuesday next, and not on Sunday, as announced yesterday.

div.head: FIELD OPERATIONS.
div.p: The 2nd Battalion Royal Berkshire Regiment was exercised this morning in field operations in the direction of Sidi Bishr, under the supervision of the Brigadier General Commanding.

div.head: THE NEW ENGLISH JUDGES-
div.p: It has been stated in the local Press that the three new English judges are to be appointed to the native courts at Zagazig, Assiout, and Beni Souef. No decision on the subject, however, has as yet been arrived at.

div.head: H. M.'S GARRISON CHURCH OF ST. GEORGE.
div.p: The Right Rev. Bishop Morley, D.D., Arch- deacon of Egypt, will preach at the parade ser- vice on Sunday next at 11 am. The full band and choir of the 2nd Battalion Royal Berkshire Regiment, supplemented by the organ, will take the service. Visitors will be welcome.

div.head: SUEZ CANAL.
div.p: On the 25th inst. 12 vessels passed through the Suez Canal. Of these, 7 were British, 1 German, 1 Dutch, 1 Russian, and 1 Italian. The transit and passenger dues for the day amounted to 314,048.07 frs. The total transit and passenger dues collected from the 1st to that date on 319 vessels amounted to 8,329,118.81 frs.

div.head: COLLISION.
div.p: A serious collision occurred this morning at 11 o'clock in Cherif Pasha- street between cab No. 1619 and a cyclist messenger in the service of Messrs. R. and O. Lindemann. The cycle was smashed and its rider thrown to the ground and injured in the temple. The victim was carried into Mac-Gregor's pharmacy, where first aid was given. The cabman was arrested.

div.head: PORT SAID BY THE SEA.
div.p: Port Said is doing its utmost to attract a share of holiday-makers in the summer months, and with this end in view two projects for building casinos are being studied, the one near the Minerva Baths and the other on the West jetty, fifty metres from De Lessep's statue. The latter is to be built on the lines of the Nice Casino, in the open sea.

div.head: THE BERLITZ METHOD.
div.p: The principles, never departed from in any of the 226 Berlitz schools, are: 1. Exclusive use of the foreign language; 2. Direct association of the thought with the foreign tongue-direct perception; 3. Teaching the concrete by object lessons; 4. Teaching the abstract by association of ideas; 5. Teaching the grammar through examples. Every teacher teaches only his own language. Alexandria, 26, rue de l'Eglise Copte, Cairo, 1, Sharia Kamel Private trial lesson free. 24820-1

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: His Highness attended prayers to-day at El Abasireh mosque, in the Ras-el-Tin quarter. The Governor was present. His Highness afterwards drove to Ras-el-Tin Palace, where he is spending the day. In the evening he re- tarns to Montazah.

div.head: OBITUARY.
div.p: CAPTAIN WAKEHAM.

We regret to announce the death, which took place at Liverpool yesterday, of Captain Wakeham, who was for many years agent at Alexandria of the Leyland Lane. The deceased was well-known and greatly respected during his residence here. We beg to tender our sympathy to his widow and family.

div.head:
THE RAILWAY COMMISSION.
OFFICIAL STATEMENT.
div.p: As an erroneous idea seems to have arisen in some quarters as to the scope and objects of the recently-appointed Railway Commission we are authorised by the Ministry of Finance to make the following statement.

It has for some years past become more and more evident that the State Railways were unable to cope with the enormously increased traffic, and that sooner or later it would be imperatively necessary to incur some consider able expenditure in order to put them on s proper footing.

Now that the paramount claims of the Irriga tion and other Departments have been in part satisfied, and that the burden of taxation has greatly lightened, it may be hoped that the Government may before long find themselves in a financial position which will justify them in dealing with the Railway question and thereby meeting a universally-admitted want. A Commission, therefore, has been appointed charged with the duty of advising the Govern- ment as to the manner in which money could most usefully be employed in extending and developing the Railway system. Incidentally, they will propose any further reforms which their experience may suggest with a view of increasing the efficiency of the existing orga- nisation.
How far their recommendations will be put into practice must depend upon the amount of funds at the disposal of the Government.

The Commission consists of Lord Farrer, Mr. Oliver Bury, and Major Le Breton, all of whom are railway experts in their different lines of the very first rank. Lord Farrer, we may state, is a director of the Midland Railway Company and of the Underground Electric Railways Company of London, and in his younger days he served an apprenticeship in practical railway work on several of the English lines. Mr. Bury has been general manager of the Great Northern Railway since July, 1902, before which date he was general manager of the Buenos Ayres and Rosario Railway. He began his railway career with the London and South-Western Railway, and has had a varied experience both in England and South America. Major Le Breton has been an inspecting auditor under the Indian Government railway administration. He is already in Cairo engaged in completing his examination of the Railway accounts, a task with which he was entrusted by the President of the Railway Administration in the spring. The other two Commissioners are expected in November, and it is hoped that their recom- mendations will be in the hands of the Govern- ment by the beginning of the new year.

div.head: EGYPTIAN ARMY.
div.p: The Khedive has been most graciously pleased to approve of the promotion of El Bimbashi H. L. E. Fell, Sudan Civil Administration, to be Kaimakam.

Lieutenant A. W. Jennings Bramly, 20th Hussars, having reported his arrival in Khar- toum from Uganda on the 10th inst., is taken on the strength of the Egyptian Army, from that date, with the rank of Bimbashi. He has been posted to the Cavalry.
The following transfers have been approved:- El Bimbashi H. M. Hutchinson, D.S.O., 11th Sudanese, to 9th Sudanese.
El Bimbashi B. H. S. Romilly, D.S.O., 9th Sudanese, to Camel Corps.
El Bimbashi D. C. E. ff Comyn, Camel Corps, to Sudan Civil Administration.

div.head: UPPER NILE EXPEDITION.
div.p: Major Powell-Cotton, of the Northumber and Fusiliers, is about to start on another expedition, the object of which is to explore the vast region lying between the Nile and the Zambesi. The journey will occupy about eighteen months, and the explorer will pass through that portion of the Congo territory which is very little known.

div.head:
7. RAMLEH ELECTRIC RAILWAY.
CAUSE OF THE CABLE TROUBLE.
div.p: A correspondent writes:-

Some two and a half years ago the Alexandria and Ramleh Railway Company applied to the Egyptian Government for permission to lay a nd high-tension cable from Karmous to Chatby. ere The Government consulted with the Alex- ed dria Municipality and a plan was agreed be upon as to how the cable should be laid er and its depth, as well as the street align- nament which the cable was to follow. The company laid the cable according to these ra-instructions, and the work was duly inspected under M. Principe, and also inspected as by Mr. Graham, the then Administrator of the he Municipality. The work was approved by Mr. res Graham and M. Principe and found to be in m accordance with the instructions of the Muni- ad cipality. About the time the work was finished t. the Municipality decided to relay Menasceed road, and in some places, in so doing, reduced m-the level of the road to within ten centimetres ld of the cable. At the beginning of this year the company decided to lay a reserve cable y, from Karmous to Bulkeley so as to do away chwith any possibility of breakdowns or of stoppages. The comparty applied to the

Government for permission to lay this extra cable. In April, the company commenced to work from Bulkeley and had completed as far as the cemetery adjoining the Rosetta Gate, when work was stopped by the Municipality because, technically, the formal permission to lay the reserve cable had not been granted. This permission was not given until two months later, and the work d had to be suspended during this time. Surely it would be advisable if the Municipality obviated such mishaps by advising the company as to what roads they were going to take up Four or five times the cable has been found to be broken at places where the Municipality have been digging up the roads. If the control of the Ramleh Railway is to be handed over to the Municipality the poor company is sincerely to be pitied, for it will be far better under the Ministry of the Interior, which has a technical and capable electrical engineer to supervise. Only this week it has been discovered that the road at the back of the German Hospital is to be lowered forty centimetres. Therefore the company forced to relay the cable an extra forty centimetres. Owing to this, a few days ago, when the trenches were open for the purpose of lowering the cable, it was struck by lightning and was burnt to the extent of 150 metres. The Municipality is fully aware of all the 1 work that is being done. Why, then, does it not advise the company as to what it intends to do with the different streets through which the cable passes!

div.head: CATTLE PLAGUE
div.p: During the week ending yesterday,64 deaths have been reported throughout Egypt as due to bovine typhus. They are distributed as follows: Gouvernorats 2,, Lower Egypt 57, Upper Egypt 5, showing a diminution of 19 compared with the previous week.
Since the beginning of the epidemic the total of deaths amounts to 146,482, distributed as follows: Governorats 852, Lower Egypt 53,506, Upper Egypt 92,124.
One new locality (Tel Rezan) was reported infected last week. No animals were inoculated.

div.head: THE PILGRIMAGE.
div.p: 300 pilgrims have arrived here from Cons-tantinople and are leaving for Jeddah via Suez.

div.head: ABBAS HELMY THEATRE
div.p: "ERNANI."

Owing probably to the meagre success which attended the first performance of this opera, the house last night was very poor. The performance, however, was successful and would have been excellent all-round but for the soprano part, which was somewhat lacking. Signa. Amelia Chiostro's style seems to begin with a soft and slight tone and end in screams. Sig. Pagani, as Ernani, was excellent, and met with enthusiastic applause. Sig. Borione, bary- tone, and Sig. Baldelli, bass, also played their parts satisfactorily.
ALHAMBRA THEATRE.

The management was obliged last night to modify the printed programme owing to the indisposition of M. Marmier. Blanchette had to be substituted by Monsieur Badin and Bou- Louroche, the performance of which proved as successful as on the first occasion. M. La l'a Claveri was particularly good in the part of The audience was equally
Boulouroche
satisfied with the musical interlude. Mlle. Blanche d'Orange's songs met with general applause, as did M. Minart's excellent "creations."

div.head:
EGYPT'S TRADE.
SEPTEMBER RETURNS F
div.p: The Customs Returns for the month of September enable us to take stock of the ia volume of Egypt's trade during the first three- The quarters of the current year. A glance at them -a is sufficient to show us that the commerce of y.the country is surpassing all previous records. Ex-The figures of the total trade for the first nine ed months of the year for 1903 and 1904 are as follow-
Jan. to Sept.
Imports Exports
Total
Thus, with only three-fourths of the year En gone, Egypt has increased her trade by consi- iderably more than four millions sterling over ed 1903, which was itself a record year.

The imports last month amounted to LE d 1,742,088, as against L.E. 1,516,567 in the es corresponding month last year-an increase of rLE. 225,521. Exports, however, fell off last le month, and there was a sum of L.E. 57,905 y less than in September, 1903. The figures of were L.E. 1,036,741, as against L.E. 1,094,646. e This falling-off is, however, too small to be

noticeable in view of the fact that the total d exports for the nine months show an increase d of over two and a quarter millions. Of this a total diminution in exports last month by e L.E. 57,000, cotton accounts for all but LE 110,000, as the exports of cotton in September tamounted to L.E. 768,901, compared with tLE. 103,070,-a decrease of L.E. 46,958. But the total cotton exports for the nine months were L.E. 10,806,203 as against L.E. 8,748,173 in the same period last year, an increase of L.E. 2,058,030.

The expansion indicated by these figures, great as it is, is subject to a further addition a if one considers that the Customs export tariff, which forms the basis of the returns from which the above figures are taken, undervalues the cotton so much that from 15 to 28 per cent. may safely be added to the returned values.
Of the cotton exported during the nine =months of this year to the 30th ulto., the Unit ed Kingdom has taken to the value of L.E. 5,040,697.

div.head:
THE MUNICIPAL LANDS,
REGULATIONS OF SALE.
div.p: The following are the concluding draft regu- lations for the sale of the lands belonging to in the Alexandria Municipality
ART. 10.-L'Administration est tenue de consigner le terrain à l'acheteur dans un délai S de deux mois à partir du jour du paiement intégral du prix.

Cette consignation sera faite sur place, moyennant simple mise en possession de l'ache-in teur du terrain, en lui indiquant les limites In portées sur les avis de mise en vente et sur le plan y annexé.

Les procès-verbaux de consignation seront te faits en double au verso des contrats de vente A et seront signés par les acheteurs ou leurs représentants, ainsi que par les agents chargés de la consignation.

Il est permis de prendre livraison par mésu- bu rage contradictoire, mais, dans ce cas, l'acheteur sera tenu de payer 1 pour cent sur le prix de vente, sans toutefois que ce montant puisse ph etre moindre d'une demi-livre égyptienne ou no supérieur à LE 10, et il sera fait mention de Ca ca mesurage sur les procès-verbaux de consi- ley gnation.
ART. 11-Des ventes pourront être consén- ties par paiements échelonnés, mais, dans ce cas, il y aura lieu d'obtenir l'autorisation de la in Commission Municipale pour les conditions à W établir.
Ces ventes devront être transcrites au greffe

des tribunaux mixtes, aux frais des acheteurs qui devront acquitter, en même temps que le sti premier versement du prix de vente, les droitsme proportionnels afférents à la transcription. ART. 12.-la Municipalité se réserve le ing droit de prescrire pour certains endroits, des im conditions spéciales concernant la façade, le mode de construction, le délai d'achèvement de la construction, etc. conditions qui seront indi- Di quées dans le cahier des charges y relatif, Mi lequel déterminera également les sanctions que pourra comporter l'inobservation de ces
conditions.

Les ayants-droit successifs de l'acheteur devront se conformer à ces prescriptions. ART. 13.-Dang le cas où un terrain vendu se trouverait loué au moment de la vente, Mr l'acquéreur sera tenu de reconnaître le bail Da pour sa durée entière. Il aura droit aux loyers Dip à partir du jour de la consignation; mais, par fiel contre, il sera tenu, à partir du même jour, au He paiement des impôts.
Au cas où la Municipalité aurait pergu le loyer par anticipation, elle devra tenir compte He à l'acheteur de la part lui revenant sur ce
loyer..

ART. 14.-Si le mesurage fait an moment de la consignation fait ressortir une différence de contenance, soit en plus soit en moins, avec la contenance indiquée sur l'avis de mise en vente, le prix de vente sera augmenté ou diminué proportionnellement à la différence en
plus ou en moins.

ART. 15. Si pour des raisons dont elle sera seule juge, la Municipalité se trouvait dans l'impossibilité de consigner les terrains vendus, 4 elle ne sera tenue qu'à la restitution du prix, avec les intérêts, calculés à raison de 5 pour cent, à partir du jour du paiement de chaque somme, et la vente sera considérée comme nulle et non avenue, sans que l'acheteur puisse réclamer aucune autre indemnité pour quelque cause ou sous quelque prétexte que
oe soit.
ART. 16.-Los aoquéreurs des terrains de la
Municipalité auront comme titre de propriété des actes de vente faits en double et sous seing privé. Les frais de transcription et tona autres frais sont à la charge des acheteurs.

ART. 17.-Les actes de vente ne peuvent, être donnés qu'au nom de l'adjudicataire, à moins que celui-ci n'ait déclaré, au moment de la vente, qu'il agissait en qualité de man- dataire et qu'il n'ait fait connaître le nom de em son mandant, en requérant la motion au of procès-verbal d'adjudication.

ART. 18.-L'acheteur ou seg, ayants-droit devront se conformer à tous les règlements de police ou de voirie, aux taxes ou impositions établies, ou à établir, ainsi qu'à tous les règle ments municipaux, existants ou à venir, sans pouvoir prétendre à aucun privilège.

div.head: A NATIVE FUNERAL
div.p: We regret to have to announce the death, be which took place yesterday, of the wife of of Mustapha Pasha Abou el Ez, one of the nota- stbilities of our town, after a few months' illness. 05 The funeral left the Pasha's residence to-day es about noon and was largely attended by re 6. presentatives of both the European and native be communities, amongst whom were the Moudir, al the Sub-Moudir, the principal Mondirish offi secials, etc. On the passage of the cartage is through the Rue de la Bourse all the shops. by were closed as a token of sympathy with Mus tapha Pasha.

div.head: PERSONAL
div.p: Mr. J. Inglis, British Consular Agent, has gone for a week's rest at the American Mission 73 Hospital.

div.head: ELECTRIC LIGHT.
div.p: Electric light is becoming appreciated here The Société Electrique de la Basse Egypte has n already erected about 800 lamps in shops, Thouses, and cotton factories, and 400 are still to be erected. The different electrical supply sshops have also put up about 400, lamps.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: The Duke of Connaught is expected to pay a visit to Egypt this winter.
H.H. Prince Mohamed Aly will receive at the palace of H.H. the Khedivah Mother every Friday between 2 and 5 p.m.
H.H. the Maharajah of Thalawar and suite, including Thakur Amras Singh, A.D.C., Dr. Ram Lal, and Major R. Benn, C.I.E, arriv ed in Cairo yesterday and are staying at iShepheard's Hotel.
His Highness gave a dinner party in his private dining-room in evening. He is leav ing shortly by the P. & O. S.S. Egypt for s India.
Ghazi Mukhtar Pasha arrived at Cairo yesterday at 1.35 p.m. by special train from Alexandria.
Saba Pasha, Postmaster-General, left Alex- andria for Cairo yesterday afternoon on official business.

Several dinner parties were given at She- pheard's Hotel yesterday. Among others we noticed Mr. J. Currie's party of 10, including Capt. and Mrs. Kennedy, Capt. and Mrs. Bay- ley, Mr. and Mrs. Brown, Major Phipps, Capt. Vaughan, Mr. Brunyate, and Mr. Dunlop.
Mr. and Mrs. A. H. Perry had a party of 5, including Miralai and Mrs. Penton Bey, Sir William Garstin, Lord Edward Cecil, and Col. Watson.

We regret to state that Mrs. von Tschudi is still seriously ill from the effects of eating the meat on the recent voyage of the S.S. Cleopatra from Trieste to Alexandria. Yesterday even ing the patient's condition gave signs of a slight improvement.
Mr. Brunton has been appointed Sub- Director of the Administrative Service at the Ministry of Justice.

By the S.S. Grosser Kurfürst (13,000 tona); which is due at Port Said on Sunday morning next, a large number of passengers for Egypt are arriving, amongst whom are Baron and Baroness von Biegeleben, Herr Georg Blass Mrs. Cecil Crawley and children, the Hon. Mrs. Davey and children, Frau Oekonomierat von Dippe, Herr and Frau L. David, Mrs. Mans- field de C. Findlay and children, Mrs. Garner, Herr and Frau Ernst Gross, Herr and Frau E. Paravicini, Mme T. div.head: CHRONIQUE JUDICIAIRE
div.p: TRIBUNAL MIXTE DE COMMERCE D'ALEXANDRIE
LES DROITS DES REPRESENTANTS

MM. Antonin Goubert et J. Assaf vien- nent d'assigner la Cie d'assurances "L Mutuelle de France et des colonies" deva: t le tribunal mixte de commerce d'Al xan drie. Voici les motifs contenus dans l'as- signation.

"Attendu que les requérants ont été char. gés depuis plus de trois ans par la Société assignée du mandat d'agents généraux de cette société en Egypte, avec pouvoirs dé- terminés et pour une durée illimitée; que ce mandat a été ponctuellement exécuté par eux; que l'un d'eux, le Sieur Joseph J. Assaf a même créé à Alexandrie un bureau spécial pour le service de la société en dépensant à cet effet L.E. 270 pour installation, personnel, petits frais, etc.

"Attendu cependant que malgré le zèle apporté par les requérants au service de la Société assignée, celle-ci n'a cherché pendant les dites trois années, qu'à mettr des entraves à l'exécution des fonctions qu'elle leur avait confiées; que dernière- ment, elle s'est même permis de désigner à leur lieu et place pour la même gestion, sans que ce fait ait été notifié aux requé- rants, les Sieurs E. Almasy, A. Félix et Cie, commissionnaires à Alexandrie;

"Qu'enfio,sans avis préalable,sans motifs sérieux, sans aucune proposition d'indem- nité et sans qu'aucune faute ait pu être relevée contre les requérants, la Société as- signée a, par sa lettre du 20 mai 1904, retiré formellement son mandat aux re- quérants;

"Attendu que ces faits ont causé aux re- quérants un préjudice dont la Société doit les indemniser; qu'en tenant compte des frais faits et des bénéfices qu'on pouvait raisonnablement attendre de la gestion de l'agence d'une société prospère, le préjudice ne saurait être évaluée à moins de L.E. 2 270;"
Me Orfali s'est présenté pour les deman- deurs et Me Vermond pour la Société dé- fenderesse. L'affaire sera plaidée le 19 décembre prochain,

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: Le marché a brillamment débuté ce matin. L'Agricole a même atteint 10 1/2 et la Delta 15 5/16; mais vers la clôture on a fléchi sur toute la ligne par crainte de complications imminentes entre l'Angle- terre et la Russie. A Londres les valeurs égyptiennes sont en faveur, l'Agricole à 10 1/2, soit 8/8 de hausse et la Delta à 15 1/2, soit 3/4 de hausse. Les transactions N ont été nombreuses spécialement pour T l'Agricole.
La Daïra est cotée 21 7/16 nominal ici et 21 5/8 à Londres.
Il y a fléchissement sur la Banque Na- tionale à 22 5/16 l'Ancienne Emission et à 22 1/8 la Nouvelle, sans affaires.

La Wardan tombe en clôture à 7 5/16, les F Markets à 23/9, la. Nungovich à 8 13/16, les Tramways d'Alexandrie à 139 1/2 les Privilégiées et à 362 les Dividendes, l'Agri- cole à 10 3/16 et la Delta à 15 1/8.
La Salt and Soda se maintient ferme à o 26 et les Eaux du Caire haussent à 955 acheteurs.

div.head: Municipalité d'Alexandrie
div.p: AVIS
La Municipalité met en adjudication la fourniture de M3 12.000 de pierre pour dallage de Chaussée. Le cautionnement est fixé à LE. 480.
Le cahier des charges est déposé au Bureau de la Voirie où il peut être consulté par les intéressé tous les jours de 9 h. à midi, les jours fériés exo-piés.
Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 6 décembre prochain.
Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation le même jour à 5 h. p.m.
L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention: Sonmission pour la fourniture de pierre pour 6- dallege de Chaassés."

Le csationnement ou le reçu d'une banque. té d'après les conditions du cahier des charges, devra être remis au Secrétaire Financier avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 6 décembre prochain en à midi.
Alexandrie, le 24 Octobre 1904.
L'Administrateur (signé) W. P. CHATAWAY.
AVIS

Le Jeudi 10 Novembre 1904 de 10 h. a. m. 1 h. 8p. m. la Municipalité procèdera à la vente aux e- enchères publiques près des cimetières Earopéens sis à la Porte-Rosette, d'une quantité des pierres extraites des terrains des Fortifications par lots de 40 à 100 m8.
Les schetears devront déposer le 10% an moment x de la vente et effe tuer le paiement du prix intégral à la Casse Municipale, le lendemain du jour de l'Adjudication.
Ils auront à supporter les droits de carrières au profit de is Ville et devront enlever les pie res schetées dans un délai de cinq jours, sous peine de 1-foile enchère pour compte de l'Adjudicataire.

div.head: EGYPTIAN MINING ACTIVITY.
div.p: In view of the existing activity in Egyptian Mining, the Directors of the London and Paris Exchange have retained the services of a competent Mining Engineer, whose reports on the present position of the various properties is of the utmost importance. This Information is at the disposal of Clients. Correspondents contemplating Investment in Egyptian Mining Enterprises would be well advised in communicating with the Exchange before doing so, and thus avoid the loss of capital incurred by the purchase of worthless securities.
The London and Paris Exchange undertake the purchase or sale of all classes of Mining Securities on the London Stock Exchange and Continental Sources.

SUDAN IRRIGATION.
By Sir Hanbury Brown, K.C.M.G., late In- spector-General of Irrigation in Lower Egypt, and formerly in Upper Egypt.

In winter the Blue Nile discharge shrinks to from 400 to 200 cubic metres a second, or, in other words, to from 35 to 17 million cubic metres a day, sufficient for a million acres, if we use the minimum discharge as determining the area, or for a million and a-half acres, if we use the mean discharge.

In summer the Blue Nile discharge at Khartoum may be anything between 200 cubie metres a second and nothing. In 1903 it fell to nothing. So that, without storage of water, summer crops cannot be grown by irrigation from the Blue Nile. And so we come to the question of water storage, and to the consideration of the advantages offered by Lake Tsana as a reservoir.

Mr. Dupuis gives the area of Lake Tsana itself as 3000 square kilometres, and of its catchment, exclusive of the lake area, as 14,000 square kilometres. The rainfall he assumes to be one metre per annum, falling almost wholly in the four months June, July, August, and September. The proportion of the rainfall that reaches the lake he takes as 25 per cent. The outflow from the lake is calculated to be 8,000,000, cubic metres a day as a mean for the year.
Calculating in the same way as in the case of the White Nile lakes, we have the following
Rainfall-
square metres.
cubic metres.
Catchment area, excln-
sive of lake ares..
Lake area.
Total from rainfall
Outflow.
Balance, quantity evaporated..
Mr. Dupuis applies a check to these figures by making the calculation with independent data, and obtains the following figures, which are practically the same:-
Quantity entering lake.
Quantity discharged.
cubic metres.
Quantity evaporated.

This shows that evaporation disposes of 55 perc cent of the rainfall reaching the lake, and that the depth evaporated is 1-21 m. a year. The lake area is to the total catchment area as 3 to 17. The range of levels in the lake is given as 1 to 2 m., and the average is said to be 11 m. From the foregoing calculations Mr. Dupuis concludes that the effective reservoir capacity of the lake is 3000 million cubic metres, and adds that it may fall to 2000 millions in a year of scanty rainfall, and rise to 5000 mil- lions in a year of abundant rain. Sir W. Garstin accepts the figure of 3000 millions as pro- bably obtainable. If, now, this total available volume is concentrated in the outflow of 100 days-a regulator, to be built at the outfall, being kept closed for the remainder of the year the discharge obtainable would be 30 mil- lion cubic metres a day, sufficient allowing for loss on the way for about two million acres of land under perennial irrigation. But perennially-irrigated lands should, for the sake of rotation of crops, have a supply of water available at all seasons. Now, we have seen before that the natural winter discharge of the Blue Nile is, at its lowest, sufficient for one million acres only. If, then, we make allow- ance for keeping up the Blue Nile discharge in winter to 300 cubic metres a second, so as to provide sufficient for a gross area of 1,500,000 acres, the quantity available for storage for use during the 100 days of summer W will be reduced to 2000 million cubic metres, in and the gross area of land under perennial of irrigation to 1,500,000 acres; and this is, be apparently, the maximum that the Sudan can be expect from the Blue Nile and Lake Tsana, There may be other reservoir sites still to be discovered on the Blue Nile itself or on its affluents; but if favourable sites are found, there is still to be solved the problem of filling them, and at the same time of avoiding silt deposit in the reservoir. In the present state of want of knowledge concerning these rivers, there is little to be gained by doing more than mention the possibility. The study of this question is included in Sir W. Garstin's list
as items 2 and 5.

As regards the work necessary to convert Go Lake Tsana into a reservoir to store 3000 fai million cubic metres, Mr. Dupuis recommends a regulator being built at a site on the out-pic flow channel about 10 kiloms, distant from the lake. The regulator would have forty openings of of 3m. each, with its floor sunk 4m below the the high-water level in the lake; it would be in capable of passing 30 million cubic metres a day 347 cubic metres a second-and would have to hold up 2m. head of water. The rock bed above and below the regulator would have ger to be cut down for some distance to form the the channels of approach and discharge,
Were such a reservoir made, a barrage near

Wad Medani would also be necessary, to provide for the distribution of the summer water to the lands lying to the Gezireh, south of Khartoum between the White and Blue Niles, and to the lands on the right of the Blue Nile.
(To be continued.)

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit - within certain necessary limits- free discussion.

div.head: REDUCTION OF GARRISON.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.

Dear Sir, Since the Boer war successive Secretaries of State, Royal Commissions, and Committees have been proposing schemes for the improvement of the military defences of the Empire. Efficiency with a big E was at first the cry, but as the anxiety caused by the war is gradually being forgotten, while its financial burden is ever with us, Economy s to-day a more alluring bait to dangle before the British taxpayer-and voter. And economy is the easier of the two to effect.

To reduce expenses by disbanding some regiments in Great Britain would not appeal much to the man in the street. But to increase the home garrison and at the same ime decrease expense is a valuable election- Bering asset. For it must be borne in mind hat any military unit is less in numbers and cheaper to maintain in England than broad; en paranthèse, it is also far less efficient. In that unworthy letter from "Common- ense," which you published on the 21st instant, we are told not to protest because a protest would be futile. Surely it is at once the duty I nd the privilege of every British citizen to a rotest against anything which he thinks is f the detriment of the Empire. As for saying is a sectional or a hole-and-corner agitation, what does he mean! I have heard opinions adverse to the reduction expressed by all classes of the British community. Hole-and- corner would appear to apply only to the laces occupied by the correspondence in your valuable columns. How would he have one rotest? Should one go with flags and anners through the streets crying, "Varus, arus, give us back our lost legions 1" To ut the matter in a nutshell. Some two and a alf years ago, when the British barracks at Chartoum were finished, a British regiment was eded to garrison, that salubrious spot. It as not found possible to spare one from egypt and one was brought from outside, thus increasing the Army of Occupation by one regiment. What is the vast change that p ermits Egypt to be suddenly denuded T all its English cavalry, all its English of tillery, and one English battalion! Will Common-sense" tell us ! It must be a adden one, for it was only discovered just in me to stop the usual reliefs. Or it must be a ery subtle one to have eluded until now the Den eyes of Lord Cromer and Sir Eldon Gorst, A ch ever ready to effect any economy that th Des not impair the country. No one under-th ands as well as the former the political and economic needs of Egypt. During the twenty ars he has been here his work has been that a far seeing and determined statesman. Every angel has been gradual and long thought-out. H his last change is in its nature so unlike at one has learnt to expect that one may pause and wonder who initiated it. When, lo addition, one believes it not for the benefit British interests in Egypt and not for the benefit of the British army, not to protest may in accordance with "Common-sense," but it contrary to the instincts of an old soldier

div.head: THE ASSOUAN DAM AND THE TEMPLES.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.

Sir,-I should be the last to cavil at the gneral trend of your leading article in to-day's gazette, but at the same time I think you have led to note some important points in the question at issue between the lovers of the turesque and of the past and the iconoclasm the Irrigation Department of the Ministry Public Works. However much we may be o nkful to Sir William Garstin and his band English officials, who have made the Irrrigation Department a most striking sample of glo-Egyptian efficiency, we may be some- at dubious as to the sympathy of these gentlemen when they have to decide between contending claims of Irrigation and cryptology. Even where there is no question she of irrigation the Public Works Department is by no means to be trusted as a conservator of ancient remains. I remember a striking case in point. Some time back,-about two years ago, I believe,you published a letter from Mr. Somers Clarke on the subject of the destruction of an interesting shrine at Assouan by the Public Works Department. This letter of that distin- guished architect and archaeologist was a seath- ing indictment of the careless iconoclasm of the Public Works Department, and there was no attempt on the part of the officials to contradict those serious allegations. If there had been any loophole in Mr. Somers Clarke's charges I am sure the Public Works Department would have been only too delighted to have availed themselves of it. But they could not find one, and this serious example of the vandalism of that Department is a disquieting symptom to all those to whom the archaeological treasures of Egypt are a source of study and delight. For how can we be sure that that Department will be more careful in protecting the temples of Nubia Philae is doomed and that most beautiful spot in Egypt has been sacrificed to the material exigencies of the fellah. But the raising of the Assouan Dam will extend the lake further into the second catar- act reach, and it is therefore incumbent on the Government to state what steps are to be taken to safeguard the temples in Nubia. Aesthetic culture is not a necessary concomi- tant of the curriculum of Cooper's Hill, and the alumni of that defunct institution, who now guide the destinies of the Irrigation De- partment, should not alone be consulted on this question. Doubtless Sir William Will- cocks will exclaim, "Let the dead bury the dead," while Sir William Preece adorns the columns of the Times with such expressions as "sentimental rot." These gentlemen, how- ever eminent they may be in their special lines, are not, I submit, qualified in the slightest degree to discuss the value of the imperilled and unique vestiges of Egypt's past. The remarks e of Sir William Preece in his letter to the Times are characterised by an ineptitude which makes anyone, who has the smallest pretensions to scholarship, shudder at their puerility. For example, he remarks, "Visitors ascending the Nile become surfeited with Ptolemaic and Roman parodies of pure Egyptian culture, and irritated with the political morality which threw over the beauties of Greek arts to foster an effete and decaying civilisation." Anybody lo who can pass such an unhistorical judg- ment on the relations of Hellenism to the Egyptian cultus, whether in the Ptolemaic m or in the Imperial epoch, stands self-con-ba demned. He may be an excellent engineer but he is quite unfitted, to decide as to the claims of Philae or any other relic of antiquity in Egypt. Sir William Preece, Sir William Garstin, and Sir William Willcocks are great experts in special subjects, but they are no more entitled to decide as to the claims of the temples vis-a-vis the Dam than is an expert co chauffeur or a professional cricketer, and the I Egyptian Government will be guilty of a gross F abuse of its position as the trustee to the world th for the priceless remains of the many civilisa- 80 tions which have borne sway in the Valley of the Nile, if it does not hearken to the Egyptologists and the savants in their demands for a guarantee of the security of the temples in view of the raising of the Dam.

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY.
div.p: FOOTBALL.
BOULAO R. INSTITUTE v. B. A.

This season's first match was played at the gro Railway Institute ground, Boulse, on Friday last, t before a goodly number of admirers of the sport. po The visiting team was the 4th Mountain Battery wil of the Royal Artillery. The Boulse esptain, on bal winning the tres, elected to play with the sun at his l back The Mountain Battery kicked off and it was evident that the lighter team meant to wear down the heavier men of the Artillery. Lloyd Jones the seeing an opportunity, centered to Eau, who passed to Cory, the ball rebounding from one of the Artillery backs, and Essa shot home, thus scoring the first goal of the season. Play was resumed, but wh the Mountaineers held the foe at bay until the kill whistle blew. Boore half-time: Boalse 1, Artillery O. G On claiming the game it at once became fast, she ball travelling the length of the field several time. Essu made the goal-post rattle with a quick shot which caused the ball to rebound into the field of play. Hayes made use of the opening and dashed into gal the ball. thus scoring the second for Boulae. We The Artillery then changed their mode of attack by long shots for goal. But Appleby was ever on the alert and saved his charge repeatedly. The play from start to finish was fast and both sides played game that will be remembered by the spectators as one in which they saw the game played in at 8 gentlemanly spi-it. The Artillery goal-keeper saved many hot shots. The Boulae forwards promise to give a good amonut of themselves this season, the combination and quick passing being especially noticed. The football-loving public will be pleased to know that every Friday they will have the chance of seeing a match at Boulso, and the members of the Railway Institute will be pleased to see clos them at these matches.

R. INNISKILLINGS. ABBASSIEH. A correspondent favors us with the following socount of last Saturday's football match at
Abbas ieh :-
FIRST HALF.

The Inniskillings won the spin of the coin and elected to play with the wind at their backs. Great cheers were given when Gen. Blade, with a well-directed kick, sent the ball well into the Inniskillings' territory, but Nixon returned Friday with a neat punt to midfield. Falion took up Bat the pass and parted to MeCourt, who ran the

ball into touch. On the throw in Krarey came away and sent a smart shot across the goal month. Bartleman, catching it up shot wide of the posts. On the kick out Walsh got posses- sion and raced well down the wing, only to be pulled up in time by Lawrence, who returned smartly. A hand ball against Lees relieved the Inniskillings' goal. Some tricky work by Smith enabled Fallon to get within shooting distance, but he was robbed in the nick of time by Ferney. It seemed that Abbassieh goal would fall when Reilly came flying down the wing and with a swinging shot banged straight for goal. Iron- marsh fisted out, but Walsh esatehing the rebound shot nested the first goal for the Inniskillings amidst great cheering. The leather was soon in mosion again, Lees parting to Bartleman, who tried a long shot which went wide of the mark. On the kick out some neat play was witnessed by the Garrison right wing, but Williamson soon spoiled their good work by tipping the ball into touch. On the throw in it seemed that the Gar- rison tearn would equalise, and Heather, with a dropping shot, just grazed the tar. On the kick out Miller passed the ball to Cunningham, who ran the ball to the 12 yds. line and sent in a scorcher, but Ironmarsh was on the alert and saved splendidly amidst great applause. At this stage of the game the Garrison team were working for all they were worth to snatch the equalising points.

Bas the grand defence play of Shanks and William- son kept all danger away. A free kick for the Gari- son soon brought play hovering around the Innis- killings' goal. MoMulan, with a high shot, was nearly making the game level, but Gillespie was not to be caught napping and fisted out twice in succession, much to the delight of the Inniskillinge supporters. Miller soon turned the tide by driving well down the field. Fornley returned and Collison got possession and had a hard try, but Gillespie soon aleared his posts. A free kick against Smith for fouling Krarey brought play once more to the Inniskillings quarters and a well-directed shot from Ferney deserved a goal. It just missed the mark by inches. On the kick out Cunningham made things look lively around the Garrison goal, but was robced when he was in the set of putting his side Another goal up, Lawrence relieving. Play was in midfield when the Referee sounded the whistle for half-time, leaving the score 1 goal to nil in favour of the Inniskillings.
SECOND HALF.

The Band of the 20th Hussars livened the spects. tors with a selection, and after the usual interval of a few minutes' rest, both teams took the field to baule the 2nd half. The Garrison team soon started operations, Lees coming away, but was soon pulled up by Nixon, who let his forwards away. Mo- Court was responsible for some good work by the Inniskilling forward rask, but was fouled by Ferney.mith took the kick, Cunningham catching the ball on his head, sent to Walsh, who let out for goal. Ironmarsh had to concede a corner to avert disaster. Brilly took the kick, Cunningham just apping the bell over the bar.

One the kick out the Garrison left came away but the Inniskilling half-backs seemed a stone wall in the garrison view. Fallon got hold of the leather and ported to MoCourt, and that player was cheered time after time for his tricky work till finally be tipped the ball to Fallon, who banged the bal through the posts, but the points was disallowed owing to his being offside, much to the dissappoint- ment of the Inniskuling followers. On the kick ons Heather brought play well down the field, but was upset by Miller, much to the amusemet of the spectators. Miller sent the ball into touch from the throw in, Nixon passed to Reilly, who caused some trouble around the Garrison goal. Once a "daisy outter" struck the posts and rebounded into play and Walsh, estebing it, was brought to the ground with a foul. Nixon took the kick and with a terrific drive sent the ball at cannon speed throug posts amidet deafening cheers. It seemed all up with the Garrison team now, for no sooner had the ball been set in motion than Cunningham let drive a long shot, but Ironmarsh fisted out, Heather punt ing well up the field. Shanks returned again with a strong kick. With only 8 minutes to go it seemed that the Inniskillings would increase their lead. A hand ball sgsinst Swith relieved pressure, bus Nixon sent the ball back to the Garrison quarters. Play was raging in the Garrison territory when the whistle sounded for full time, leaving the Innis- killings winners of a well-fonght and hard contested Game Hoores :-
Inniskillings 2 Goals Abbassieh Garrison
ST. ANDREW'S CLUB.

The committee of the Saint Andrew's Club met on Wednesday for the purpose of considering what steps should be taken with regard to fixtures, ete, for the season now about to begin. It was unanimously resolved that a general meeting of the members, together with all parties interested in the olub, should take place on Tuesday evening. 1st proximo, at 9 o'clock, at Café Zarani, Cherif Pashs-street, in the Balon de Poker. The committee hope for a good attendance at this meeting.

PROCLAMATION.
Import of Cattle into Egypt from the Sudan (via Halfa.)
The following proclamation cancels all previous regulations published on the above subject.

The import of cattle (balls, cows, calves, and buffaloes) into Egypt from the Sadau (via Halfa) can now be effected under the following conditions:- 1.-Each consignment should be accompanied by a Sadan Government Veterinary Officer's certifion to stating that:-
(a) They were in a good state of health and free from disease on leaving the Quarantine Park at Halfs.
(b) They have been segregated, prior to the issue of this health certificate:-
Cattle for slaughtering, for 48 hours.
Cattle for draught purposes, for 8 days under Quarantine.
(e) There had been no case of infectious disease amongst them.
2.-All Cattle before leaving Halfs must be brand with the letter "8" on the near hip.

8. The number and destination of animals should, on the arrival at Halfa, be notified to the Egyptian Government Sanitary Authorities, Cairo, by the owners, indicating whether they are for slaughtering or draught purposes.
4. Cattle for slaughtering; besides Ghizeh Market, they can henceforth be sent by rail direct to the following towns, viz. :

Beni-Bonef, Fayoum, Minieh, Assiout, Bobag, Keneh, Luxor, Assonan, where they should be kept under observation in the places indicated by the Loos! Authorities or in the Abattoirs until they are slaughtered.

5. Cattle for draught purposes having completed 6 days Quarantine in accordance with article 1. (b) may be despatched to any station in Upper Egypt; permits therefor will be issued to owners in so- cordance with particulars stated in their demand (vide article 8).

6-In the event of any outbreak of contagious disease amongst the animals. subsequent to their leaving Halfa, the regulations adopted by the Quarantine Board and approved by the Egyptian Government must be strictly observed.
